title: MGM Stories: The Greatest Studio
summary: Examines the rise of MGM and its founder Louis B. Mayer, setting the tone for how Hollywood icons were made in the studio era.
utterances: MGM was more than a studio; it was a cultural force.
Louis B. Mayer shaped star-making for decades.
Hollywood’s golden age began at MGM.
transcript: Karina Longworth explores how talent contracts, image control, and the culture of the lot forged the first generation of movie stars.

title: The Many Lives of Howard Hughes
summary: Unpacks the legend of Howard Hughes—tycoon, director, and aviation pioneer—through his tumultuous Hollywood years.
utterances: Hughes left a mark on both aviation and motion pictures.
His reclusiveness became as famous as his films.
How much of the legend is real?
transcript: Investigates Hughes' business ventures, romances, and his relationship with stars like Katharine Hepburn and Ava Gardner.

title: Marlene Dietrich: Reinventing Stardom
summary: Tells how Dietrich became a symbol of reinvention, sexuality, and European glamour in classic Hollywood.
utterances: Dietrich’s persona was ahead of her time.
Her collaboration with Joseph von Sternberg set the tone for star directors.
Self-mythologizing shaped her Hollywood legend.
transcript: Longworth breaks down Dietrich’s partnership with directors, evolving style, and the creation of a persona that thrived through war and scandal.

title: Jean Harlow: Blonde Bombshell
summary: Profiles Jean Harlow, cinema’s original 'Blonde Bombshell,' whose career and tragic end redefined female celebrity.
utterances: Harlow’s films changed Hollywood’s depiction of sexuality.
Her death at 26 remains a source of myths.
Typecasting and studio politics shaped her legacy.
transcript: Discusses Harlow’s rise, relationships, and the mysterious circumstances around her early death.

title: Joan Crawford: Star by Design
summary: Explores Joan Crawford’s rise from poverty to Oscar-winning stardom, including her feuds and infamous later image.
utterances: Crawford’s carefully managed image was pioneering.
Ambition sometimes clashed with personal relationships.
Her legacy would inspire both admiration and parody.
transcript: Covers Crawford’s transformation, key movies, and the legacy left in the wake of 'Mommie Dearest.'

title: Charlie Chaplin: From Vaudeville to Icon
summary: Traces Chaplin’s transformation from vaudeville performer to global film icon and political exile.
utterances: Chaplin’s persona blended humor with social commentary.
His political views led to exile from the US.
The Tramp remains a cultural touchstone.
transcript: Analyzes classic films, relationships, scandals, and Chaplin’s lasting influence on comedy and film language.

title: Orson Welles: Boy Wonder
summary: Follows Orson Welles’ early rise, Citizen Kane, and battles with Hollywood’s power brokers.
utterances: Citizen Kane upended film artistry and business alike.
Welles' ego and vision were both asset and curse.
Hollywood resented outsider innovation.
transcript: Examines Welles’ artistic battles, the mythmaking around his genius, and his struggle with the Hollywood studio system.

title: Olivia de Havilland: Breaking the Contract
summary: Spotlights Olivia de Havilland’s legal fight for actor’s rights, reshaping the balance of power in Hollywood.
utterances: De Havilland’s court victory gave actors new freedom.
Studios once held lifetime control over stars’ careers.
Legal battles can change show business.
transcript: Chronicles the lawsuit that ended studio-era contract bondage and its ripple effects on star power.

title: Clark Gable: King of Hollywood
summary: Tells the life and career of Clark Gable, the ultimate leading man in Hollywood's golden age.
utterances: Gable’s image as ‘The King’ was carefully crafted.
He defined a generation of masculinity on screen.
Personal tragedy and WWII service deepened his legend.
transcript: Longworth details Gable’s stardom, iconic roles, and how his life intersected with historical events.

title: Judy Garland: The Perils of Fame
summary: Explores Judy Garland’s talent, Hollywood pressures, and her struggles with addiction and mental health in the spotlight.
utterances: Garland’s voice and vulnerability captivated audiences.
Studio pressures began from her teen years.
Mental health struggles were poorly understood and treated.
transcript: Traces Garland’s continued impact on culture and LGBTQ communities as a symbol of resilience.

title: Lana Turner and the Scandal of Stompanato
summary: Dives into the notorious murder of Johnny Stompanato and the complicated life of star Lana Turner.
utterances: Turner’s career survived scandal after scandal.
Hollywood’s true crime stories shaped her public image.
The Stompanato case set legal precedents.
transcript: Explores Lana Turner’s trajectory from ingenue to tabloid queen and the aftermath of her boyfriend’s killing.

title: James Dean: The Rebel’s Legacy
summary: Reflects on the short life and cultural legacy of James Dean, and how his death shaped Hollywood.
utterances: Dean’s image became a countercultural symbol.
His death at 24 froze him in time.
Hollywood learned to sell tragedy.
transcript: Longworth analyzes three key films and the myth-building around a lost generation talent.

title: The Blacklist: Art and Politics
summary: Explores the Hollywood Blacklist—when actors and creators were barred for leftist politics in McCarthy-era America.
utterances: The Red Scare upended careers overnight.
Blacklist victims built new lives under pseudonyms.
Censorship and politics shaped art’s future.
transcript: Spotlights screenwriters, directors, and actors who fought for creative freedom and paid the price in lost work.

title: Bela Lugosi: Hollywood’s Dracula
summary: Bela Lugosi’s journey from Hungarian stage to iconic monster and the realities of horror stardom.
utterances: Lugosi brought European gravitas to horror.
He was typecast as the monster.
His life was marked by loneliness and addiction.
transcript: Longworth discusses horror’s rise in the 1930s and the sacrifices stars made for fame.

title: Gone with the Wind: Movie and Myth
summary: Examines the making, impact, and controversies around Gone with the Wind, and its place in Hollywood history.
utterances: Gone with the Wind became a cultural phenomenon.
Its production was an epic itself.
Race and myth continue to surround the film.
transcript: Covers production drama, casting struggles, and the complex legacy of the movie’s depiction of the Old South.

title: The Children of Hollywood
summary: Explores the unique pressures and challenges of children growing up in the public eye in golden age Hollywood.
utterances: Child stardom shapes identity for life.
Family, ambition, and media attention mix unexpectedly.
Success at a young age has hidden costs.
transcript: Shares stories of Shirley Temple, Judy Garland, and others—how early fame shaped and disrupted lives.

title: Rita Hayworth: Love Goddess
summary: Charts Rita Hayworth’s controversial career, personal reinventions, and her struggles with image and control.
utterances: Hayworth’s marriage to Orson Welles made headlines.
Transformation was both tool and burden.
Icon status hid a private pain.
transcript: Explores Hayworth’s breakthrough roles, personal and professional challenges, and her battles with identity.

title: The Legend of Bogie and Bacall
summary: Recounts the partnership of Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall—romance, film, and legend-making.
utterances: Bogart and Bacall defined the classic on-screen couple.
Their relationship changed press coverage of Hollywood.
Tragedy and love made their legend endure.
transcript: Delves into their first meeting, collaborations, and the public’s fascination with their real and screen romance.

title: Mae West: Sex and Censorship
summary: Explores Mae West’s career as a sexual trailblazer who pushed past censorship, scandal, and Hollywood prudery.
utterances: Mae West made bawdy humor mainstream.
She was jailed for defying ‘decency codes’.
Her legacy changed American popular culture.
transcript: Chronicles West’s legal struggles, artistic innovation, and how she remade the rules for women in Hollywood.

title: Frank Sinatra: My Way
summary: Looks at Frank Sinatra’s career ups and downs, the Rat Pack, and his influence on 20th-century celebrity.
utterances: Sinatra’s comebacks set records in every decade.
Music, film, and politics all intersected in his life.
The Rat Pack’s wild legacy remains.
transcript: Longworth traces Sinatra’s musical evolutions, Hollywood years, and relationships that defined the image of 'Ol’ Blue Eyes'.
